question.text: The increasing use of mobile phones and computers makes people lose the ability to communicate face-to-face. To what extent do you agree or disagree?

questionType.explanation: You must clearly state how much you agree or disagree with the statement that technology reduces face-to-face communication abilities.
requirements: State your position clearly (strongly agree, partially agree, or disagree)
Give specific examples about technology's impact on communication
Address counterarguments if taking a balanced view

keyWords.definition: Growing frequency and amount of usage
keyWords.importance: Shows this is a current and ongoing trend
The specific technology types to discuss
Strong claim about skill deterioration - you can challenge this
The traditional communication method being compared

keyWords.definition: How much or to what degree
keyWords.importance: Signals you can take a nuanced position, not just yes/no

essayStructure.introduction: 2-3 sentences: Paraphrase question + clearly state your position (agree/disagree/partially agree)
essayStructure.body1: 4-5 sentences: Main argument supporting your position with examples
essayStructure.body2: 4-5 sentences: Second argument or counterargument with examples

commonMistakes: Not taking a clear position on the extent of agreement
Ignoring positive uses of technology for communication
Overgeneralizing that all technology use is harmful
Not addressing different age groups or contexts
Forgetting to discuss what 'losing ability' actually means

steps.title: Build Paragraphs
steps.completionCriteria: Complete all 4 paragraphs (10+ words per blank)

content.instructions: Fill in each blank to build your essay paragraph by paragraph. Aim for 10-15 words per blank.

paragraphs.name: Introduction
paragraphs.template: It is often argued that _____ [paraphrase the question]. While I _____ [state your position], I believe _____ [provide nuance or main reason].

blanks.label: Paraphrase the question
blanks.hint: Restate the idea about technology and face-to-face communication in your own words
blanks.placeholder: e.g., the widespread use of mobile phones and computers is diminishing people's ability to interact in person

blanks.label: State your position
blanks.hint: Choose: completely agree / partially agree / disagree
blanks.placeholder: e.g., partially agree that excessive digital communication can weaken interpersonal skills

blanks.label: Provide nuance or main reason
blanks.hint: Add depth to your position or state why you hold this view
blanks.placeholder: e.g., technology also offers valuable opportunities to enhance and maintain meaningful communication across distances

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 1
paragraphs.template: On one hand, _____ [topic sentence]. This is because _____ [explain the reason]. For instance, _____ [give a specific example]. As a result, _____ [state the consequence].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - main argument
blanks.hint: State your first main point clearly
blanks.placeholder: e.g., excessive reliance on texting and instant messaging can indeed weaken face-to-face communication abilities

blanks.label: Explain the reason
blanks.hint: WHY does this happen? Explain the mechanism
blanks.placeholder: e.g., digital communication removes the need to practice reading non-verbal cues like body language and facial expressions

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Give a concrete example about young people, texting, or social skills
blanks.placeholder: e.g., many teenagers who primarily communicate through social media apps often struggle to maintain eye contact during in-person conversations

blanks.label: Consequence
blanks.hint: What is the final impact or outcome?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., these individuals may develop social anxiety and find real-world interactions increasingly uncomfortable and challenging

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 2
paragraphs.template: However, _____ [topic sentence presenting other side]. The reason is _____ [explain why]. For example, _____ [specific example]. Therefore, _____ [conclusion].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - counterargument or second point
blanks.hint: Present the other perspective or your second argument
blanks.placeholder: e.g., technology also provides valuable tools that facilitate and enhance communication in ways impossible before

blanks.label: Explain why
blanks.hint: Explain the reasoning behind this point
blanks.placeholder: e.g., video calling platforms enable people to see facial expressions and body language even when separated by vast distances

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Give concrete example about video calls, accessibility, or connection
blanks.placeholder: e.g., international families can maintain close emotional connections through weekly video chats, which preserve the visual elements of communication

blanks.label: Conclusion
blanks.hint: What does this mean? Wrap up this perspective
blanks.placeholder: e.g., this demonstrates that technology can complement rather than replace face-to-face interaction when used thoughtfully

paragraphs.name: Conclusion
paragraphs.template: In conclusion, while _____ [summarize main concern], I believe _____ [restate your position with final insight].

blanks.label: Summarize main concern
blanks.hint: Briefly acknowledge the concern about technology and communication
blanks.placeholder: e.g., excessive digital communication can diminish opportunities to practice essential interpersonal skills

blanks.label: Restate position with final insight
blanks.hint: Clearly restate your view and add a thoughtful final point
blanks.placeholder: e.g., the key issue is not technology itself but rather the need for individuals to consciously balance digital convenience with regular in-person interaction

content.instructions: Now combine your paragraphs into a complete essay. Aim for 250-280 words total.

introduction.purpose: Paraphrase question + state your position clearly

body1.purpose: Discuss how technology weakens communication with reasons and examples

body2.purpose: Present counterargument or benefits with reasons and examples

conclusion.purpose: Summarize + restate position with final thought

checklist: Introduction clearly states your position on the statement
Body paragraph 1 discusses main argument with specific example
Body paragraph 2 presents counterargument or second point with example
Academic and topic vocabulary used appropriately
Examples relate to texting, video calls, or social skills

modelEssay.text:
In today's digital age, many people argue that the widespread use of mobile phones and computers is diminishing people's ability to communicate face-to-face. While I partially agree that excessive reliance on digital communication can weaken interpersonal skills, I believe technology also offers valuable opportunities to enhance and maintain meaningful connections.

On one hand, excessive dependence on texting and instant messaging can indeed harm face-to-face communication abilities. This is primarily because digital communication removes the need to practice reading non-verbal cues such as body language, facial expressions, and tone of voice. For instance, many teenagers who primarily interact through social media platforms often struggle to maintain eye contact, interpret social signals, or initiate conversations during in-person meetings. Research indicates that young adults spend an average of five hours daily on digital communication, significantly reducing time available for face-to-face socializing. As a result, these individuals may develop social anxiety and find real-world interactions increasingly uncomfortable and challenging.

However, technology also provides valuable tools that facilitate communication in ways previously impossible. Video calling platforms like Zoom and FaceTime enable people to see facial expressions and observe body language even when separated by vast distances. For example, international families can maintain close emotional connections through regular video chats, which preserve many visual elements of communication that pure text-based messaging lacks. Furthermore, digital communication offers accessibility benefits for people with social anxiety, hearing impairments, or speech difficulties, allowing them to communicate more comfortably and confidently.

In conclusion, while excessive digital communication can diminish opportunities to practice essential interpersonal skills, I believe the key issue is not technology itself but rather how people choose to use it. Maintaining strong face-to-face communication abilities requires conscious effort to balance digital convenience with regular in-person interaction.
